text: Out of town, here to eat. If your driving here to eat...no. Ribs were dry and average. Hype only. Food is edible. Service: okay. Location: loved area and has street parking.
Terrible food accompanied by even worse service! If you want bland food and rude servers this is your place. With so many great places near by I would highly suggest steering clear!

Old school, with a great bar and ambience that takes you back, you can just imagine Sinatra in one of the back tables. Ribs are some of best I've tasted, I like them a bit crispy with the tangy sauce. Delicious. Great onion rings. Service is prompt. Expect to wait.
Exceptional ribs in a VERY casual atmosphere. Love this place. Great, friendly service. Wide selection of beers. I will definitely return.  Positively no dancing!

A Chicago institution worth visiting. Given Twin anchors is well known for their chicken and ribs, I was happy with my reasonably priced ($21) combo plate. They unfortunately don't have any healthy options for side dishes so I ended up with the onion rings to complete my pig out meal. Portion sizes are generous which made up for the 45 minute wait.

Outstanding!  Have been wanting to go here for many years. I finally broke down and went last Friday!  The ribs were some of the best outside of Memphis, TN. THE SAUCE WAS FLAVORFUL, with just a hint of spice. The ribs we cooked to perfection and the meat just fell off the bone. It was some of the best BBQ I've ever eaten in Chicago!  I will be going back again and again!

Solid American Bar and Grille with BBQ. If you picture what you expect from an American BBQ place, this place should come to mind. Her Royal Highness (wife) , my daughter had just left the Ginza Fest when my daughter pointed to this place and said that they had good BBQ. I asked the boss and she allowed it. I had BBQ sandwich, chili and a baked potato. All of them matched up to my expectations and since that is what I wanted, I was satisfied.

I moved to the neighborhood and was really looking forward to going here. I had heard they had the best ribs in all of Chicago. A lot of people go visit this place because of the hype. I think this place used to be good, but now it has just turned into a business. Get as many people in and make as much money as possible. The food quality is just not there. The ribs were burnt and everything else was from a freezer bag. It's not terrible food, but the quality is not there.

Fun old school restaurant clearly with a lot of history. Place was from the 30s/40s which was cool, and they had been making their ribs the same ever since. The only move according to the waitress was to get the ribs so I complied. I got a full rack with zesty sauce and prohibition (spicy) on the side. The meat was really tender and charred to perfection. The sides of fries and cream spinach were great too, and a good balance with the meat. The service was outstanding, and we were not rushed at all like we thought we may be.
Such a great spot and place. Food is amazing. Staff is so nice and friendly. Great spot to people watch.

I like this place a lot. Unassuming and comfortable. Ordered the full slab of ribs and wasn't very hungry yet I ate the entire thing. Get the Probibition sauce. Order a few extra sides of sauces with the ribs (it's free) you will need it by the gallon. Some of the best ribs I've ever had. Also ordered 2 cocktails that were amazing. I see why Frank Sinatra frequented the place. I would definitely return.

Pretty good ribs, amazing ice cream bars from Cupid Candies, and excellent service.  Been around forever and featured in a number of movies. Do The Second City tour or show, then walk around the block to this place.
What a great place to eat. Cute area and the food was amazing.

Excellent ribs.  Wish they were smokier but they are what they are and I don't think there are better ribs in this part of Chicago. Sauces make up for the lack of smoke.  Great selection of beers complement the meat.  If you get there early, you can avoid a long wait, especially on weekends.

I've been wanting to visit this place since I saw it in "Return to Me."  We were in town to to see a baseball game at Wrigley, so I surprised my wife with a visit to the Twin Anchors.  It has that definite neighborhood feel to it and the staff makes you feel right at home.  The menu is varied enough for even the pickiest of eaters.  Service was great and the atmoshpere was what I was hoping for, too.  I hope to go back to both Chicago and the Twin Anchors.
Good old fashioned ambiance! Like going back in time in old Chicago. We had the burgers and ribs. Kid friendly too.
Great food and a fun atmosphere. A bit buys, but I guess that's what you get when the place is this good. The ribs were to die for and their creamed spinach - YUM!

Fall off the bone ribs like you read about.Lot of variety in the sides (beans and onion rings are great, skip the fries). Great beer selection and awesome atmosphere. Very busy, but after you put your name in, try to snake your way into a bar seat and enjoy this tavern for everything it is. Thank me later. PS get prohibition sauce

Got there right at 5:00 on a Monday, so got in right away.  Great atmosphere, friendly service, average sides.  As everyone else mentions, the meat falls off the bones on the ribs.  Tender, melt-in-your-mouth, all meat no fat.   But, because they have been cooked so long they are short on flavor.  All you can taste is the sauce.  I would go back just for the atmosphere.  Walk there from Lincoln Park on a nice day.  It's in a lovely neighborhood.

Cannot say enough great things about Twin Anchors! The atmosphere is fun and unique, and the beer list is fantastic- tons of local breweries supported here! And then the FOOD. Omg. It's fantastic. These are probably the best ribs I've ever had in my life. They are fall off the bone tender and served with a sauce of your choosing (get the prohibition!!) on the side so you can slather on as much on as you like! The beans and spinach for sides are delicious too, packed with favor and complemented the ribs nicely! The onion rings, which I'm not usually a fan of, were also great.  The only con of this place is the wait, which can be up to an hour on a random weekday night. But what do you expect from a place this good?! Don't let the wait get in your way of trying this place- you might even be able to snag a seat at the bar where you can order food like we did to avoid waiting! Definitely a hidden gem that I will be returning to over and over.
good ribs but they were oddly small.  the beer list is what really brings it up to four stars.

Classic old-school joint. Strong drinks, fresh food, good service, solid draft beer selection. Ribs are why you come here. They are not traditional southern ribs so if you're a BBQ purist it's probably not your thing. These are uniquely Chicago style. But the babybacks are young, tender and fall of the bone delicious. Dry-rubbed with your choice of BBQ sauce on the side.The Prohibition sauce is sweet, spicy perfection. Onion rings are top-notch! Racks tend to be small so do yourself a favor and order a whole slab. Nice locals. Sit at the bar if you want to be entertained. Everyone talks to everyone. Best jukebox in Chicago.

I spent my bachelor days dining at Twin Anchors 50 years ago. It was great then and it's still great today.  Most restaurants change over the years, owners, menus, prices. Twin Anchors is still a neighborhood bar and restaurant, that offers just what we were looking for 50 years ago, and they are still offering it today. Small, cozy bar and dining area, convenient location, great ribs, reasonably priced wine and beer--my kind of place to dine.  It's been 50 years since I last dined at Twin Anchors, but it won't take me very long to return!  F. Coggin

I came here with some coworkers and my manager when visiting Chicago. Not to confuse this with Twin Peaks, as I had originally thought it was called (which is a completely different atmosphere and perhaps not appropriate for a coworker dinner),  I do LOVE the atmosphere of Twin Anchors though. This restaurant has been around since the 1940s and they have kept the old-school, retro decor. It's very charming and cozy and you can just breathe in the history.  The ribs are pretty good, a little on the smaller side and not a lot of meat on the bones, so if you are feeling hungry you should opt for the full rack. Not to worry though, if you get the half and want to add on, they will do that for you and you can just pay the price of the full rack (instead of two half racks, which will cost you much more). Admittedly, this is not the BEST ribs I've had, but they are decent. The meat falls easily off the bones and with the sauce it is perfect. The spinach side was also great, but very heavy on its own.  It kind of reminds me of a spinach dip appetizer that you would normally eat with pita chips or bread.  I think what pushes this place to four stars is the ambiance. It's worth a visit if you are ever around old town!

This is a classic Chicago corner bar/restaurant serving delicious basic fare. The ribs are cooked right, crinkle fries and side BBQ sauces are delivered warm-that's key. Don't miss their prohibition sauce. They're doing a great job with a nice craft beer list for what appears to be just a neighborhood joint. Old school atmosphere, far enough from the Well St d-baggery and very hospitable staff.

I didn't like anything about this place. Worst martini I have ever ordered, and though the bar service was very friendly, the waiter was not. Almost nothing I could eat on the menu as a GF person, which isn't unusual, but they were not accommodating. I won't go back, especially to wait for an hour before being seated.

I haven't been here in 20 years but nothing has changed. Twin Anchors is a hidden gem in Chicago! The Ribs are  always perfect and fall off the bone. I prefer the Zesty sauce. Get the Onion Rings with the Ribs. Best value appetizer are the homemade chips with Blue Cheese.
Great ribs and great service. No reservations so wait times can be long but I often do carry out.
Best ribs ever !!! They have different sauces , but you can't go wrong. Onion rings are a must!
That's incredible!!!! Ribs are amazing !!! Real american style!!!! Can't wait to come again!!400N state chicago

Prohibition sauce is my jam.. so good.  Ribs are pretty damn good but honestly anything would taste great with that sauce. Chicken tenders are big and juicy, but my fave is the ribs. Cozy atmosphere that's perfect for a cold winter night in Chicago. No frills place with good food.. can't go wrong

Very cute place and fun to see so much history. Almost doesn't feel like you are in the city, which is pretty cool. Food was good too. We had the ribs, pulled pork sandwich, and chicken sandwich, which were all decent.

First time here and my family and I were very happy.  Ribs were delicious, chicken was tender and juicy.  Pulled pork was outstanding and the kids said the chicken tenders were excellent.  The sides ( baked beans and Cole slaw) we're very tasty.  Service was excellent which always compliments the meal.  We walked from Lincoln Park Zoo and is was well worth it. Thank You

Top ten ribs ever. Been there for eighty years. "Old Blue Eyes" locus. Further comments unnecessary! Local scene and crowded on a Thursday night. Always a good sign. Hard working and friendly crew, nachos straight out if the frier and great selection of beers. A must when in Windy City!

These were by far the best ribs when I first moved to Chicago 10 years ago and I used to go here all the time and recommend to my friends and out of town co-workers.  The order was always the same, full rack of ribs with a side of the prohibition and zesty.  Lately I've been using take-out and the last few orders of ribs the meat portions where noticeably smaller and some bones had little to no meat.  The last order I placed from here the ribs came very burnt (the point where you can't taste the meat but the burnt part) and dry that I was regretting not just making chicken or pork at home and just using the sauce instead of eating the ribs.  I was so disappointed I was considering driving back to the restaurant to return them if it didn't take 20 minutes to get back there (no one should pay $25 for burnt ribs and still walk away hungry).   I contacted the restaurant via their email to voice my displeasure but no one bothered to respond so I probably won't come here or recommend anymore.   The place doesn't take reservations and it's always packed so be prepared to wait.
Twin Anchors food is excellent and the best ribs in town! Very tender and choices of sauces. Staff is very friendly too. Worth the trip.

You can't find a better place for outstanding ribs, very friendly wait staff and a nice selection of beers.  Our waitress went out of her way to address the dietary needs of one of our friends who is highly allergic to dairy products.  Great atmosphere and a great venue to take out of town guests to a true Chicago favorite.  Order the ribs and onion rings with a side salad and enjoy.
The Chicago vibe was great.  Off the beaten path and worth the adventure.  Ribs and chili is the specialty of the house.

You have to go at least once....  I like the place, but it's just OK.  Here's how I grade it: Atmosphere - A+  (old-school antique charm) Service - A+ Very nice, Fast, etc... RIBS - C-  Seriously, they really lack flavor.  Not good.  Maybe they boiled them to death. Chicken - C - Again, very bland... nothing special.   Parking is very tough but they do have a valet. There are some great old pictures and history associated with this place.  Next time I'll order a burger.  They're sort of on the expensive side for ribs, so I would expect better quality.  Oh... and they trim the ribs so that they are a bit smaller than what one would expect, much small... almost as if they cut off the ends for rib tips but cut off too much.

Sunday at 5pm, a 15 minute wait and voile a table for 2! This place is known for ribs and they do not disappoint! Dry rub with sauce on the side, like ribs should be served! And the flavor combined with the tenderness...perfection! Salads and homemade sides, delicious. Can't wait to come back to Chicago for a repeat preformance.
A Chicago must. This cozy neighborhood diner makes you think you've stepped back in time. Great barbecue ribs, close to Second City, North Beach.

Not everyone's cup of tea when comes to BBQ but is fall-out-of-bed location for me. Not a connoisseur of BBQ but guessing this sweet base is ~Memphis style? Anyway Frank S picture here and good enough for me.  Usually a wait, drinks OK .  Nice to take the tux off and go native.
My favorite rib place in Chicago. It's a classic building and it's small, so you might have to wait in line for a long time. You have to try the prohibition sauce.

In le 00s i was hired 2 ghost write something 4 a writer who put me up on the Gold Coast because LA was "The A**Hole Magnet" according to him &we ordered food from here He wanted to give me a classic Chi City BBQ experience & this place was the one that had the most history When the grub arrived, he pretended 2 have lost his wallet &i had 2 pay & so el tema de ese proyecto was established.   Nonetheless, the baby back ribs (my standard BBQ) were worth it.  I especially remember the sauce & how open the people were in The Chi City 2 actually getting 2 know mi & not just what they could get from mi. I don't like LA hate, cuz hate doesn't solve anything but anyone who thinks that anything but themselves & LOVE is the answer to their problems is weak  The food from here was memorable enough to write about today

Heading to Second City and one of the friends in our group suggested this restaurant...  Super excited EXCEPT... hubby and I are paleo right now and the idea of looking at BBQ and old fashioned's (and that creamed spinach!!!) without tasting them seemed torturous.  BUT NO!!!  I got this 1655 Ahi Tuna salad that was amazing.  Like, not just paleo amazing... actually amazing.  Keep in mind... this place is tiny and crowded. I loved it.  The location, the ambiance, the history, the food... but if you are looking for quick, cheap, spacious, and well lit... this won't rate 5 stars for you.

I've been here before and the wings were fresh and delicious. I came with a friend Sunday afternoon and the wings and chicken tenders were room temperature.  I also don't mind paying $12 for a Bloody Mary but my god, it was weak as hell!  won't return

This is THE Ribs place in Chicago.  I have been visiting for Ribs for over 25 years!  In town with my 19 year old son who enjoyed seeing where we (wife and friends) used to hang out when we younger.  The place is old, but frankly looks exactly the same as when I first walked in.  New is the latest BBQ sauce.  The Twin Anchors sauce is a tangy sweet, and the new sauce is more traditional thicker and spicier.    My son liked the new sauce on everything, I thought the new sauce was great on Wings, but I love the tangy sweet sauce on ribs.  Also new are Micro Brews (big improvement from 20 years ago)!    TIP for those who don't want to stand around fighting for bar space... put your name in at Twin Anchors, and walk down to Marge's for a beer and walk back an hour later.
Love this place. Family owned and you can taste it in the food. The ribs are amazing and so is the sauce!! Walking inside you feel like you're walking into old Chicago- it's awesome.

A restaurant with lots of history! When you walk in and look around at the old bar and round booths it takes you back to your grandparents era of men smoking and ladies wearing fur, lots of jewelry with cocktails flowing and live entertainment. It has so much history and the pictures on the wall tell the story. I wish the walls would talk, the stories they could tell.  This place was a big hit with Frank Sinatra and many other famous celebrities from past to present.  I've been here a few times and tried lots of items on the menu, but my favorite is the ribs. The ribs fall off the bone and are not fatty at all. Cooked to perfection and super juicy  that they just melt in your mouth.  This place is super popular and on weekends it gets pretty packed starting at 4:30 p.m. If the wait is long, just sit at the bar and enjoy a cocktail. If you don't want to wait then go around 4 and you should be able to get a seat right away. No reservations.  Its a family, friends or date night type of place. Its not pricey at all.  I'm already planning my next trip, that is how great of an experience this place is.

The boyfriend swears by this place, but I'm not usually a rib eater. I have to say, I am a fan of the prohibition sauce. We got there at 530 PM on Saturday and had an hour wait for 3 people. This place is always packed, apparently.

Just go here, my god, go. Drop what you're doing, get into your car, train, plane, or walking shoes, and go here. Drop whatever other restaurant you were considering and walk in the door of this place and never look back. You will walk out a different person.

Docked a star because of the blondish, mid 20's-ish hostess.  She was so unpleasant, I have to write a review and hope for management's attention because I was unable to have it that night.  I'd never been inside before; only ate outside when I first discovered this place this past summer.  Walk in, not sure where to "check in." Find something that looks like a host stand and said hostess kind of wavering around but not giving me any eye contact or acknowledgment. "Hi, is this where I should check in?" ".........(major eyeroll) um...YEAH. (one larger eyeroll).  My friend and I instantly knew we were outta there. On our way out, tried to look for a manager but it was a busy night and we were STARVING.  Please don't be such a terrible brat to your patrons. We like your BBQ and don't want to have to worry about facing your unpleasant wrath if I happen to ask you where the bathroom is next time. Total bummer.

Ok - just left. First timers ( I have always wanted to go). OMG, fabulous place.  Yes a step back in time, for all of the right reasons. If you walk out of here not satisfied there is something seriously wrong with you.  Ribs- unreal. Atmosphere, the best. Service, attentive and prompt. It is truly a great place- a Chicago classic.

Twin Anchors is a Chicago favorite. It has been open in the same spot since the 30s, a true testament to how good it is. Old school atmosphere, small seating area and great BBQ. I prefer the zesty sauce above the other options and have had better onion rings but the pulled pork sandwich keeps me coming back. I hear their ribs are the best in town. Definitely go visit for something different and laid back.

Awesome restaurant. It felt like a neighborhood pub, with a great environment and really good food. The ribs were delicious and came right off the bone. We also had the ice cream for dessert and it was delicious. Lots of Batman pictures on the walls since there was a scene filmed there for the Dark Knight. Definetly worth checking it out.

A Chicago institution.  A must if visiting.   I'm not a ribs gal but their pulled pork is delicious. Love the extra spicy Prohibition Sauce too.  Definitely a cheat meal day if you know what I mean.   And I love their No Dancing tees.

Zoiks! Hard to believe this place is still in business. The food, mostly diner style menu, is really good but the place is just a dinosaur. I guess that's all that matters.  The service is swift, casual and polite.

I came here for dinner around 6:30 on a Wednesday night and the wait quoted to me was 2 HOURS. On a Wednesday? I figured it had to be good. So I put my name in, and luckily only had to wait about an hour fifteen.  The place is kinda divey, but I think that's part of appeal. However, because it's so popular, it's also very crowded...even once seated, the tables seemed super close together and it was hard to make it to the bathroom through the people. Besides that, the service was great and despite the crowd, our waitress was very attentive.  The food - out of this world. I ordered the ribs (get a full rack. I don't care if you're on a diet or whatever. Get the damn full rack. I don't judge). Coupled with the prohibition sauce, which definitely has a kick to it but isn't unbearable, these ribs were amazing. The meat was tender and they were cooked to perfection. I ordered onion rings as a side, and they might be the best damn onion rings I've ever had. You know when you bite an onion ring and all the onion comes out and you're just left with breading and it's the worst? Not the case with these bad boys. You bite in and they're cooked perfectly and the onion stays in so you can finish the whole ring.  This place is definitely worth the wait. If you can deal with the crowds, you're in for a great meal!

Place still had its old school charm which was really nice. However, if you get a side don't get the fries. They're just crinkle cut fries you can make at home. Get the onion rings or something. And hopefully you'll get a better waitress that actually pays attention to you.  Bottom line, the ribs and onion rings are delicious.

Can't say enough about this place.  The ribs are incredible - I recommend the Prohibition spicy sauce.  It's amazing for groups, and way better and cheaper than a steak night.  Only downside is no reservations, but that just means you get a drink at the bar and wait for your spot to come up.  Have been going to this place for years and will continue to.  Love it.

We tried for the first time the other day as it's on the list of best BBQ in the city. They didn't disappoint. The prohibition sauce vs zesty was happening and prohibition won. My husband had ribs and I had the half chicken. Chicken was super juicy and an excellent portion. Onion rings were really great too. The only thing I didn't like was the croutons on the ceasar salad. For BBQ the food came out incredibly fast. We had our salad like 5 min after ordering. It's a nice little divey bar/restaurant.

When someone tells you this spot is Frank Sinatra's favorite rib spot you listen.  I never really got a chance to eat in the restaurant as it is much easier to order for pickup and just eat it at the confines of your own home. But whenever I go inside I feel like I am in the dark knight movie with 2 face.  The ribs with the prohibition sauce is . Pulls apart by fork or hand. Nice bark on the outside but soft on the inside. The ribs are kind of small so if I must say just order the full slab. The fries are good but by the time i get home with them they are a little soggy but i am sure its better in the restaurant.  The jumbo shrimps are quite jumbo! They are like little lobster tails. Only comes in 4 pieces but you get like 3 bites from each one. The garlic butter is delish with it.  Rotisserie chicken is the typical rotisserie except you can add their amazing sauces to it making it that much better. Not dry at all btw.  Great food here but I definitely want to dine in next time and experience it fully.

If someone asked me for a perfect example of an All-American diner this place would be it - simple yet cozy atmosphere, a wide selection of beer (especially happy with them carrying 3 diff brews from 3 Floyds), gigantic portions at reasonable prices, screens featuring baseball games, and serving all sorts of popular classics like wings, ribs, and burgers with sides such as fries, onion rings and slaws....  We tried the wings in both zesty and prohibition sauce, and both were very good but on the sweeter side of the BBQ spectrum (another sign of being super American? =P). At first we were wondering if the prohibition sauce would be really spicy considering it contains ghost peppers, but in reality it's merely a hint of fire. The ribs also live up to the hype. So tender they fall of the bone! Only complaint is the fries it came with were very coarsely cut so it's not very crispy, but I suppose some people prefer it this way so to each their own.  The service was also extremely attentive. Highly recommend!
tastes like cock and sauce. luv it

These are the best ribs that I have ever had in my entire life hands down. If I could have one last meal, it would be ribs, so me saying that says a lot. You MUST get the prohibition sauce. AMAZING. They are so tender, juicy and they fall right off the bone. Get a full slab so you get leftovers. They don't take reservations so go around 5pm on a weekday or a weird time so you can get right in.
Friendly, clean, and the ribs with the prohibition sauce were fantastic,  A great local eatery with a fascinating history!

Wow! This place didn't disappoint! Came in around 4:30 for an early dinner before a show at UP. Waitress let us pick our booth, no wait on a Sunday afternoon.  We got a basket of fries to start. Waitress brought out all their own rib sauces. I'm not a fan of bbq or bbq sauces, but these are tasty, try them out! Zesty was by far my favorite, good flavor-spicy but not hot. Boyfriend was all about prohibition, definitely a more bbq flavor.  I got the fish fry with onion rings and boyfriend got a burger with more fries and prohibition sauce. His burger was cooked to perfection (a rarely for him). While the fish fry wasn't the best I've had, the onion rings saved the day!  I'd come back for sure!

It's been ages since I've been to this restaurant and now I remember why. The ribs had no flavor and neither did the creamed spinach. Carsons is way better than this place. I even considered giving it only two stars.
This needs zero details. It's AMAZING. GO. NOW. Ok, maybe one detail: get the prohibition sauce.

I love twin anchors. The sauces are delicious, as I have tried every single one. I absolutely love the workers. They are so sweet and get in nice conversations. I usually will get a 1/2 slab of ribs with zesty sauce.  The sides are great! So many choices! Also many people say the ribs are not smoked. It's because they aren't. They are Chicago style-fall off the bone.  I also love the interior! It's casual and fun. I go to twin anchors all the time. I HIGHLY recommend twins.

What a great place!  Just a neighborhood joint with a great story behind it.  Love the ribs, love the atmosphere, good service.  The only problem is that it's packed most nights.  It's not open for lunch during the week but on the weekend it is - go for a late lunch and take your sweet time.

This place is seriously on my top 5 list of best restaurants in Chicago. A hidden gem for sure... The prices on all food and drink is so insanely cheap! The flavor of the ribs and chx is superb. Zesty Bbq sauce is delicious. Onion rings and creamed spinach were phenomenal! Service and ambience were at its best. This restaurant is old school and charming! Please check it out. The wait was worth it!!!

Ribs were tender but BLAND. Zesty sauce had no zest.  Chili is awesome--good flavor and just enough kick. Service was great--extremely friendly place. Fries and onion rings were not very good either. Just come, get a bowl or chili and enjoy the relaxed vibe and nice people. Don't bother with the ribs or the sides.

If you come on a weekday, you can usually be seated immediately for dinnertime. Weekends are another story - be prepared to wait an hour or more! For me, a half of ribs with the creamed spinach was a perfect meal. Make sure to get the prohibition sauce - it's so good and absolutely made the meal for me. If you're very hungry, get the full slab of ribs, they are finger lickin' good.

Great bartenders making drinks with fresh squeezed limes.  NOT the mixes.   Very good tap beer selection.   Atmosphere is still as great as it was for years.   Ribs portion were small.  Chicken was dried out inside.  Dark meat portion was very small.  For the price it was overall good.  I'd come back for the price value.
Good food but not a lot of selection on the menu. Enjoyed the ambiance. Wait staff was very friendly. We had burgers and ribs and they were delicious.

Absolutely the BEST ribs in town and that I have ever eaten.  Onion rings are great!  There sauces are awesome!  Gale Street comes in second.  TA beats everyone!  Been coming here for year and I have NEVER been dissapointed.  My favorite place to eat.  I would eat here everyday if I can.

Call it exaggeration-but twin anchor ribs are arguably the best in Chicago. This dive is more than just a scene from one of my favorite movies, but rather the most perfect collection of barbecue, sides, and bread baskets you'll come across. My go-to is the half slap of "zesty" ribs, side of fries and coleslaw! The zesty is a little spicy for my sensitive taste buds-but well worth the pain. The french fries are crinkle and the coleslaw is creamy. The meat is so perfectly tender and truly falls off the bone! Be prepared for a wait if you go during peak hours but I assure you, well worth it.

Old school joint were you can enjoy the best ribs ever and speak with the locals. You just feel comfortable and hospitality from both the wait staff / bartenders and the locals themselves welcome you to enjoy their favorite spot. OH.......and did I mention the best ribs ever!!!!

Don't even look at the menu. Get the full slab w zesty sauce and onion rings.    Have a cold beer and get the heck out.  The dining room is the size of a postage stamp and they satisfy hundreds of rib eaters each night. So be kind to your fellow rib eaters and don't linger after dinner....eat it and beat it.

I have always heard how awesome this place was and I'm glad we finally got to try it yesterday. There's a ton of history here and the vibe is really, really cool.   Didn't go with the ribs (I know, I know) but the pulled pork sandwich with the prohibition sauce was also really good. Drinks were pretty standard but all in all this is a really cool place that lives up to the hype.
Loud, crowded, cramped, parking challenged...but oh sooo charming.  Great bbq and some fish, burger selections.  Nice, friendly, cheap bar to wait (likely) for your table.  Neighborhood setting.

Referred by friends, so took a trip off the beaten path, in search of the "best ribs".   This is obviously self proclaimed, as they were far from the best.   Ribs were boiled not smoked, guess that's how they do BBQ in a big city.   Onion rings were greasy, and it was obvious the oil they fried them I hadn't been changed in a while.   Gave them the one star for the history, cool place to have a drink, wouldn't go back for food.

Went to Twin Anchors for dinner yesterday after my business partner raved about their ribs and told me to try it. Went and got the half chicken and half ribs. I tried to play it safe in case I didn't care for the ribs, but I should have gotten a full order of ribs. The ribs were amazing. came right off the bone barely touching it. The prohibition sauce is fantastic, don't bother with the zesty sauce, prohibition is the way to go. My rating is strictly for the ribs, I mean, that's what they are known for. The chicken honestly was average, a little dry for my liking, but the ribs were great. The service was great, definitely recommend!

This was for 6/17. We arrived close to 9pm as we were headed to Second City afterwards. Surprised to find it not very busy and certainly no one at the bar. Maybe they all came later. Also we haven't been in years since moving out of the area. It is still the same. Same friendly service and delicious food. Fall off the bone ribs, tender chicken and surprisingly a delicious cheeseburger. But one of the biggest surprises was the dinner portion Caesar salad which was very ample, fresh and delicious. We sat in the bar and enjoyed 80s tunes but would have preferred some Frank Sinatra. Nice to see that this is the same after all these years.

My favorite ribs in the city! And I love ribs!! Prohibition sauce all the way.  You cannot go wrong with fries or onion rings.  Buy and keep a bottle of their sauces in the fridge in case of emergency!   I love the feel of the bar when you step in, reminds me of old Chicago, times past.  The menu is simple the bar is stocked so just go enjoy some ribs and a drink!
Quintessential rib spot in Chicago. Great place to sit and have a beer, too. Reasonably priced, too. Ribs and a few beers will be around $30 per person.

This traditional and well-known Chicago food stop has been on my list for years. We finally made it there yesterday evening and it exceeded my expectations! Everything was delicious, especially the ribs. Ask for some sauces on the side and you won't be disappointed. A great, casual atmosphere with a history and tasty barbecue to back it up!

Fantastic experience - filled with history and memorabilia photos -former speak easy-our waitress had worked there 25 years and the other waitresses ranged from 10 -36 years continuous service at the restaurant - the Rib slabs were tender and wonderful with several sauce options !! Now I want to watch the film 'return to me' which was filmed there P.S. I final did watch the film Return to Me- and I recommend that too!

Food - They start you off with complimentary bread & breadsticks to tide you over until your appetizers & meals arrive, which as a carbivore I greatly appreciate. Their baked beans were tasty, the chicken tenders were a little rubbery & limp with not as much crispness as I'm used to but the sauces they came with (Prohibition & Honey Mustard in my case) more than made up for it, and the cole slaw offered a nice balance to the spicy flavors. Everyone else at my table ordered the ribs, and they were all very satisfied and had nothing but good things to say about it. Beer - Good selection on tap, and plenty of quality options in can & bottle form as well.  Ambience - Old-School Chicago. Welcoming but not trying too hard. Service - Good. They said there was a 20-minute wait, and it ended up being 5. I appreciate over-estimates to under-estimates. The waitress offered to get me new tenders because the honey mustard spilled all over it. I declined, but I appreciated the offer. Historical Significance - Harvey "Two Face" Dent drank at this bar in Dark Knight. This is Frank Sinatra's favorite Rib Joint. Conan O'Brien had a birthday here. Chris Farley, Dale Earnhardt Jr., Jimmie Johnson, 80s band Poison, Joan Cusack, and others have all dined here with kind words & reviews from their visits hanging on the walls. Prohibition Sauce - This sauce is so good that 2 people I came with bought a bottle to bring home. Highly recommend slathering this on whatever you order here.
I can't speak highly enough about this location. Just a nice neighborhood barbecue joint that turns out fantastic ribs, chicken and onion rings. If you haven't been yet, you need to.

My father-in-law used to come here with colleagues after work forty years ago. He comes with us regularly now and we all enjoy the comfortable, old-fashioned charm of Twin Anchors. Wonderful atmosphere, mellow, pleasant clientele. Love it that Twin Anchors has figured out how to hold on to the past yet stay current. The food here is not extraordinary--it's simple but it's done well. We love the "Soynatra" sandwich, which is a vegetarian sloppy joe, and my father-in-law appreciates the good selection of small-plate starters, since his appetite usually can't handle an entree. This place gets packed, so come early. Parking is a pain.
One of the best restaurants in Chicago.  It's a neighborhood bar and restaurant with great foods.  The ribs are especially good and I'd go with the zesty sauce.

The best ribs you'll ever have. I grew in Alabama and have had amazing BBQ in my short lifetime but TA is clearly the best. Amazing menu choices but if you're coming on the weekend, prepare to wait. I wait an hour every time and it's ALWAYS worth it !!!

I had not been to Twin Anchors in over 20 years, and have been salivating for their Baby Backs that entire time.  Last night the wait was over, as I endured the 1.5 hour wait to be seated, and thoroughly enjoyed a feast consisting of onion rings, French fries, and a full slab basted with Prohibition Sauce. It was fantastic!!  The festive atmosphere along with a never aging decor, made this trip to Chicago a very memorable event.  If you enjoy BBQ and local flavor, get to Twin Anchors.

Get the full slab of ribs smothered in Prohibition sauce. Don't even flirt with the other two, not worth your time or attention. I had half a slab and I regret that I didn't do a full one for myself. 5 stars for the ribs and sauce, but the sides were subpar. The spinach side was way too heavy and slightly bland. The baked zesty beans were alright, but I didn't really touch those either.

A true Chicago restaurant - don't miss this (although I did last visit).  Ribs are wonderful, but not limiting it to just that! - service is spectacular and it always reminds me of my home town - Chicago.  See you this summer TAR&T!

A friend raved about the ribs...and so did the Yelp reviews.  But, I gotta say, while they were good, they were not fantastic and I've definitely had better.  The creamed spinach was really good!  As were the baked beans.  Prohibition sauce is tasty with a little kick.  Zesty sauce is apparently a classic...but I did not care for the cinnamon undertone.

Twin Anchors consistently produces good food. The staff is friendly and the food portions are considerate. It's not the best BBQ in America; however, it's a Chicago classic and hits the spot when looking for solid sit-down restaurant to enjoy with relatives or new Chicago friends.

We heard good reviews about this place and it's "fall off the bone" ribs, so we decided to stop by. Amidst the giant crowd already at the bar and tables, we were able to sit immediately just the two of us.     There is not a lot of seating, but that does not deter people from waiting up to 90 minutes for a table. This bar has a rich history that you can see on the wall, and has been frequented by stars, mainly Frank Sinatra. This is also the bar from The Dark Knight when 2 Face confronts the corrupt cop.     The waitress was extremely friendly and made us feel very comfortable. She explained our options and did not appear rushed at all, despite the packed house. I ordered the full rack of ribs because I had to while my wife got the chicken. Portion sizes were great and food was delivered swiftly. Per the waitress' recommendation I mixed the prohibition sauce with the zesty sauce and I cannot explain how perfect he combination was. I was worried that the prohibition sauce would be too sweet but it was great and definitely spicy. I only wished I remembered to ask if they sold individual bottles there. They do offer cases online but I can't convince the wife to order 24 jars haha.     This is a must see establishment while in Chicago!!!

So....I think this may be the only semi-negative review I've ever written, but I'm more hoping to help the place out rather than be negative. Hindsight's 20/20, and I should have just said something while I actually there. We got there at 7pm on a Saturday, and totally expected to wait for some time to get a table. No complaints there. This was our first experience at Twin Anchors, and we'd heard nothing but great things, so were excited to finally be trying it. We were actually pleasantly surprised when it was only an hour and 15 minute wait for two....no biggie, we can handle that. So we were standing around the front bar area just waiting, which gets pretty crowded during busy times, but again, totally to be expected! We were lucky enough to snag two bar stools at the end of the bar by the hostess stand while waiting for our table to wait it out while enjoying some cocktails, out of the way of the masses. Bad move. Those last two bar seats are RIGHT by the sink. And I dont know what they use to clean or how much of it, but the bleach smell was pretty.....overwhelming. Seriously.....it was really, really bad! I could smell it when I walked in the front door, but sitting right there by it was a whole different ball game. Just to be clear, I am not bothered by smells whatsoever, however gross or not gross that may be. I'm pretty tolerant to them, but for some reason this horrific bleach smell was making me queasy! We finally got called to our table, after waiting for an hour and 15 minutes,  I sat down and told my husband we had to get our food to go before we even saw our waitress. I broke out in some sort of weird fever or hot sweats or something, nausea, like I was succumbing to the flu, or something. And this has never happened before, but whatever they were using to clean in that sink just did me in! And I know that's what it was....I wasn't sick prior to getting there, and felt better that night after getting home. And I know what you're thinking "why didn't they just move away from the sink if it was so awful?"....well,I told you, smells don't usually bother me so i thought it would be fine. And I feel like such a high-maintenance, never-satisfied complainer even airing this out on the internet, but.....it was not a fun thing. And not to be overdramtic, but its been 2 days and I still feel like all I can smell at all times is bleach. Regardless, we ate our food at home. The ribs were seriously delicious, my burger was great, chili was amazing. But experience.....sub par. Had we not had this bleach experience, Id probably have much more positive memories of the evening. Its just unfortunate, because now I'm always going to be weary of going back here, even though the know the food is great. Its just weird how one small, rather insignificant thing can really throw a wrench in your outlook on a place. My advise to Twin Anchors.....your food is GREAT! But, the place is small and people get crammed together (which is totally what makes it charming) but the last thing you want is for something like bad smells to send people right back out the door. Cool it on the cleaning solutions during busy time! Or maybe use a slightly less "odorized" solution? But hey, at least we know its impeccably clean.

Unfortunately we were very disappointed with Saturday night's service. We arrived at 6:30 and were assured we would have a table by 7:30. After asking status of our table three different times, and each time being told "You are very close", we finally left about 8:15. The bar tender was no help, projecting a very poor attitude and service to match. I don't mind some inconvenience, I understand Saturdays are busy, but it was especially embarrassing for me since it was my idea to have dinner there. A total bust.

Awesome little spot to grab some BBQ! The ribs were fantastic and the prohibition sauce is a must. Very homie ambiance if you are looking for a chill spot to grab a drink and some ribs, staff is super friendly!

I will say I am not much of a ribs eater but I decided to do it at our work happy hour and glad I did. The ribs were amazing. I got the prohibition sauce and man oh man they were full of flavor. I highly recommend this place for a nice lunch or dinner. The restaurant is old and you can tell but it adds character to the building itself. It's been used in movies so they have some mentions of that of that on the wall as well. Our server was very nice and was very open to splitting our check 6 ways which is uncommon (goes to show they like to keep the patrons happy). All in all this was a great place and would definitely go back.  Make sure to go in earlier than later it was starting to get packed when we were leaving around 6ish on a Thursday night!!!
Best bbq in Chicago hands down!!! The prohibition sauce is my favorite...sweet and spicy goodness

I've been coming here for years for the best ribs in the city. When my husband and I want barbecue - this is where we feast. Everything is great - the fries, onion rings, chili - yum! Make sure you get a bottle of your favorite sauce on the way out!
The ribs are Boiled!! No seasoning. But when u add the prohibition sauce it was great!! The wait wasn't bad for a Sunday night. About 25 mins. Glad I made the trip!!

Nice little tavern with a supper club atmosphere & a BBQ ambiance. Read about this place so stopped in for drinks to check it out. Friendly bartenders, great drinks & talkative & informative. We'll definitely be back to try the BBQ. We got there before the rush, sat at the bar, had a couple of cocktails & when we ere ready to leave they were lined up out the door coming in to eat. It smelled & looked awesome. It's only a couple blocks off the brown line (L).
Best ribs ever! Service was wonderful, bartenders were very friendly. The place has a homelike feel, and is a definite must to check out if you like ribs.

Stopped in here for a beer and bbq before heading over to The Comedy Clubhouse - my son does improv which gives me an excuse to come to town every now and then, even in February!  The draft beer selection was very good which itself is worthy of at least a star - I had the local Revolution IPA which was excellent.  The half bbq chicken was good, but next time I'm going straight to their signature ribs.  Our waiter was competent but rather ambivalent about the whole thing.  My only real complaint is that the meal only comes with one side, and good luck finding anything green.

I lived by Twin Anchors for a few years and frequented the restaurant. They have some of the best BBQ in the city and the staff is always amazing. Tonight my car got a flat tire in front of their restaurant and they tried to help me change the tire and gave me a glass of wine on the house. The nicest people in the city work here! Customer for life!

A true neighborhood gem. I Always take visitors to Twin Anchors and it never disappoints. Guests are always impressed with how delicious and tender the ribs are. They want to take home the Prohibition sauce too. Ordered the wings, the ribs, fries, creamed spinach, baked beans, and onion rings. They were all so delicious. Oh and topped it off with the milky smooth cheese cake. Two more converts!

Got the ribs with zesty sauce and ended up using the prohibition sauce from my husband's order instead. I was worried about the heat, but a little goes a long way and it was delicious. The onion rings were great addition and there were plenty of leftovers for the next day. We enjoyed the relaxed atmosphere and good service; not fussy, but we were well attended to.
Ribs were a little overdone. Place was slammed, we waited a long time, by the time we ate it felt like they were just mailing it in. Wouldn't return.

I always mean to take a photo of my food here for Yelp, but always get distracted by the deliciousness that by the time I remember, it's too late and the plate is empty. There is a reason why there is always a wait here. The food is fantastic! I usually get the half slab with onion rings and prohibition sauce (spicy). But if you aren't a fan of the spicy, go for the zesty sauce. I've also had the chicken here too which is delicious, but nothing beats the ribs. The bartenders are well versed and make a plethora of classic cocktails. The old fashioned is tasty and does the trick on a cold day.  Keep in mind they don't do reservations over the phone, so if you have a large party, be sure to give yourself at least an hour to put your name in with the hostess and enjoy a cocktail while you wait. They have local craft beers and TVs at the bar.

Best ribs I've had in Chicago. Try the prohibition sauce -- great mix between sweet/tangy and spicy. The place feels more like a bar which serves food, than a regular barbeque joint. Also -- the onion rings are on point.

Tired, old, worn out, exhausted, are some words to describe this place.  They open at noon on  Sunday and watching people stand outside rather than letting them in to sit down within fifteen minutes of opening was entertaining to the wait staff busy chit chatting, fully aware of awaiting customers.   Last nights left overs, warmed quickly and not at all thoroughly were the fare.  The chicken was small, barely warm and nothing remarkable.  The ribs were nothing extraordinary and very bland.  The onion rings cooked in an oil in need of changing had me running to the toilet. The iced tea, from the gun behind the bar, dispensed from a box is disgusting.  The baked beans were nothing special, but the best part of the meal.  A true disappointment. The server checked on us twice, to deliver the food and then to try and sell cheesecake, no interest or visit in between.  We drove an hour to get there, risked a parking ticket as there was no valet and nowhere to park in the area and left very, very disappointed.
Come for the ribs and good company. Get some of the extra sauces on the side to experience all the flavors. Love this place. And the t-shirts are ok.

What can you say about this piece of Chicago history that hasn't already been said? Fantastic ribs, service is impressive considering the number of people that are always looking to enjoy this iconic restaurant.

Best ribs in the city. Located in a residential area, this no frills small joint has been around a while. They don't take reservations, but it's definitely worth the wait. Owner, bartenders and staff are all very friendly too. We recently brought my dad here for his birthday, and they treated him and our party of 8 great. Like I said the ribs are phenomenal, and you have your choice of sauce. My favorite is the "prohibition" sauce- nice mix of sweet with a slight kick.
This was recommended by one of our coworkers, two thumbs up.  Get the full stack with baked beans.  The meat just falls off the bone.  Cool bartender, chill atmosphere, and solid beer selection.

I know  its not 'true bbq' ribs per se (ie the def. from the 'south') as its baked in an oven. like Duh. they are not holding it out as smoked southern  'q' Double Duh. So everyone take a breath and stop trying to find a smoke ring on oven cooked ribs lmao. Thing about this place it has history, this is a tradition for me dam-u. beer selection is pretty good and I like dem ribs. place is often full so tight as all get out and used to be best freakin' rib deal in the world many many moons ago when I was hittin it regular. not so much anymore but still way okay by me. I def. don't like the cramped pissers smack dab on the wall side of main joynt area  (I told u it was tite gotta go somewhere) but I like this place it's for realzz and I just like dem bones!! They get-errr done old school style!! same wait staff for like my lifetime and im no young bearded hipster with a tite shave and cut lol! Ps Last time I tried Carsons on Ontario corner I'd say these are literally at least 10x better.  pro tip get the full slab+ rings skip the crinkle cut

I've been told for years that this place was the best place in the city for ribs. So much so, that the line would out the door on the weekends. Finally, I was able to make it there. I'm a BBQ fanatic and was extremely excited to get some authentic BBQ in the city.  These are the WORST ribs I've ever had in my life. They were dried out and "shriveled." Obviously they boil them or soak them for a long period of time before putting them on the grill. If they actually smoke them, they are terrible at it and should stop. The people on here saying these are amazing ribs have never had REAL bbq. I feel sorry those people as they have no idea how amazing ribs can actually be. I've had better ribs from the supermarket and would even consider twin anchors ribs to be BBQ. They know nothing about cooking ribs.
Great ribs without a doubt some of the best in Chicago  good place to just chill and have a drink or two and eat good

A must stop every time I visit Chicago. Who cares that the meats aren't smoked (and I own a $1000 smoker). BBQ can be done many different ways, and Twin Anchors does it their way. Expertly, and not smoked.... If it's your 1st visit the rib and chicken combo with prohibition sauce is a must! Great staff, friendly and always at your service . If it's packed (which it will be), be patient, people come to eat here, not watch sports or mingle.  I gave it 5 starts because I've never been disappointed.

If this is what Chicago considers their best barbecue then I'd be scared to eat at any other BBQ joint in the city. I read a manager's reply to a review saying they do not smoke their meat, that this is considered "Chicago-style" and they are proud of this method. Wut... So Twin Anchors is proud their meat has absolutely zero flavor. Zip. Nada. The sauce is ok - we tried all of them - but not nearly special enough to make me forget about the bland meat underneath. Their meat falls off the bone... so much so that when you pick up a rib all that's left in your hand is the bone as your meat is still on the plate. It's comical!  Also when we arrived we were told by the hostess that we would be seated "very shortly." Forty minutes later several parties had been seated ahead of us and we were starving.  Two positives: Our server, Catherine (who shares my name, bonus points), was extremely friendly and attentive, and the baked beans were delicious. I would most definitely NOT recommend this restuarant to anyone who has ever had BBQ, like, even once in their lives. Such a disappointment.

Wow. I was here with a tour of the oldest bars in Chicago recently, and this place is ... definitely old and cheesy. Apparently it's very popular for food, but I wasn't there long enough to try any. The bar/restaurant itself is not physically impressive - the wood paneling on some of the walls and accordion doors on the bathroom make it feel like you're in a camper! But, I would go back to spend more time and see what's so special about the food if someone asked me to. Just don't expect a luxe experience!

Phenomenal BBQ and an awesome bar. If you ever get a chance to go you have to try their ribs. They were so good I had to order extras to take home with me! I may even make another trip before we go back to LA. The prohibition sauce is seriously to die for!
Tasty BBQ ribs and solid drinks. Great location but still hidden away as a local gem.
What else can be said? This place is legendary. Great food in a tavern setting. You must try the prohibition sauce.

I don't get it. Hearing this was a Chicago staple and had amazing ribs I made my girl accompany me to Twin Anchors on a recent Chicago trip. We arrived and had to wait 40 minutes for a table on a Monday night, the place was packed, and as a BBQ fiend was I was really excited thinking about what a great experience this could be. Then I sat down and got some food. First off, the cafeteria style seating always annoys me in these older places. I know it's just how things are, but sitting a few inches from other people (who usually are half-drunk and yelling) just hurts the dining experience. That plus the wait would have me ordering to-go if I loved the food and lived in the area. Incidentally though, neither of those things ended up being the case. I'm from the South. We love our BBQ. One of the key things with BBQ is getting the flavor into the meat. The meat at Twin Anchors is completely flavorless and bland. It is very tender, which seems to be all most reviewers focus on, but tended isn't all there is to ribs. Ribs should be tender without falling completely off the bone, for one thing, but also they should be smoked or otherwise cooked slow and long with a proper rub or seasonings so the meat has a great BBQ flavor all it's own. THEN you add sauce to taste. Unfortunately the ribs at Twin Anchors had no flavor, fell completely off the bone in a boiled kind of way and just did nothing in my mouth at all. They honestly tasted like late-night diner ribs. The sauces were at least good. The "prohibition" sauce was a brown sugar sauce with a kick and "zesty" was your standard tangy sauce well done. Still, when the meat is worthless the sauce is no savior. Also the fries were standard frozen corporate mail-ins, and my root beer was half-flat. My girl loved the baked beans though, so I guess that's something. Twin Anchors is filled with framed signatures from "famous" people who loved the ribs, but my tourist self can't agree. Perhaps Chicago has a different goal with ribs like they do with pizza, but I'll take flavorful meat properly prepared over bland meat you eat with a fork. Southern BBQ nuts have been warned.
The prohibition sauce was delicious;  the ribs did fall off the bone but seemed a little undercooked.  Cole slaw and potato were good.

The best place to get ribs in all the city of Chicago. The prohibition sauce is SO MONEY!! I like mine with onion rings on the side, but the baked potato or fries make pretty good accomponiants too. Place is always always busy so prepare to wait and have a drink at the bar. It's one of the oldest establishments in Chicago and I promise you will fall in love.

Thank you, Frank Sinatra & Thank you, Labor Day BBQ tradition! I followed the recommendation from my boss to check out this place b/c Frank Sinatra loved the ribs here. Hopped on the brown line train from my hotel to Sedgwick, and the restaurant was only a few minutes walk away! I expected the restaurant to be crowded but there were about 3 empty tables when we arrived. I had forgotten that it was Labor Day and most people probably grilled with friends or stayed at home but I was traveling in a completely new city and I had forgotten that great tradition.  The no-wait was just such a nice, welcoming surprise after I debated so long about whether or not to dine in.  We got the ribs with chicken ($16) with baked beans and the pulled pork sandwich ($10) with onion rings. Added prohibition sauce for both and did not regret a single thing! The meat on the ribs were so tender that there was no need for a knife and although the chicken was a bit dry, dipping it in the prohibition sauce was probably the second best thing after the ribs. I loved the baked beans and the onion rings were a must! The only thing I didn't really like was the pulled pork sandwich and now I can't really remember why.  PS there is a split meal charge of $4 if you decide to split an entree.

Real deal. Cream spinach is best u will ever have. Better than $12 steakhouse creamed spinach. Bar has good selection of beers. Worth the trip. Can eat at bar if in a hurry bc restaurant is not that big. Pork lollipops do not disappoint and prohibition sauce hits the right spice notes.

My husband and I have walked by many times so we decided to give it a try.  The place is great!  The atmosphere doesn't seem like you are in a city.  You could be in a small town anywhere in America!  The walls are filled with photos of famous guests which are fun to look at while you wait.   We had the creamy spinach dip which was delicious.  I had the vegetarian sloppy joes, they were just what I wanted.  Yummmm.  My husband had the ribs and rated them "the best he has ever had!"  We will be back!

Had the ribs and chicken with pepper jack creamy spinach.  You have to do the prohibition sauce, it is awesome.  The ribs were pretty good, but the chicken was very good. The downside for a guy from Vegas that NEVER pays for parking is that the parking in the neighborhood is so confusing, permit 142?, that I had to payt. $9 for vale.

A Chicago legend.  Whether you live here or are visiting, Twin Anchors should be on your list to check off at least once. The place is kinda divey, in a nautical kinda way.  That adds to its charm in my opinion, but don't expect white table cloth fine dining.  What you can expect, is darn good food!  The ribs are amazing, but the chicken is darn good too.  If you can't decide go the combo route like I did....but if you're a rib lover go with the ribs.  They're THAT good.  For a side dish my recommendation is the onion rings - nicely battered, just greasy enough.   Do expect to wait, and I don't believe they take reservations.  If you're dining on the weekend and don't wanna wait, try getting there around like 4-5pm.  Even then we had a slight wait, but it was very manageable and there was still room at the bar to pony up for a drink while we waited.

Excellent place! Worth the wait. Ribs are amazing! I love the prohibition sauce. It pairs especially well with the sides of beans and rings. I have introduced many friends and family members to Twin Anchors. Service is positive and friendly. Much of the staff have been here for years and years. That is a great sign for a spot with great tasting food!

Pretty damn good.  This place gets packed, so plan accordingly.  We got there around 6:30 and we were able to slide into some seats at the bar.  By about 7, place was packed till about 8:30.  So you have been warned. Pretty good beer selection and they make some good drinks.  Even though there was this old timer complaining about the size of the martini glass.  But got a quick Sinatra story out of him, since he said he worked there in the 70's.   As for the food, just get the wing appetizer with Zesty sauce and prohibition on the side.  Then just get a 1/2 rack of ribs with a baked potato and baked beans.  You can thank me later. Ribs fall of the bone.  Beans have some pulled pork in them and the potato cooked perfectly.  Make sure you mix Zesty and Prohibition together, little sweet and spicy.  Great combo. Again, thank me later.
Had the half-slab of their signature ribs with the prohibition sauce and a side of onion rings.  The food was good, but the meal was a bit overpriced.  I've had better ribs at tents from RibFest.

By far one of my favorite restaurants in the city. I have never been disappointed with this place. The food is so delicious, I never leave still feeling hungry. I always recommend this place to everyone.

First off, the bread that the server brings to your table when you sit is kind of a strange flavor. The tables are small, the glasses of water are small, and i wasn't particularly amazed by the decor. BUT-the main meals came and I was in heaven. I actually enjoyed the ribs despite some of the reviews on here. I LOVED the prohibition sauce. It's got nice flavor, and it definitely warms up after a few seconds in your mouth. The zesty sauce was also delicious with a unique flavor, but my whole table was able to appreciate the tastes. I also tried some of a pork sandwich and that was delicious with both sauces that we had at our table. For sides, I tried fries (light and crispy), baked beans (amazing flavor), and one person in my party got the appetizer chips/blue cheese dip (chips were crispy and the dip went well with both the chips and fries!). The waitress was very helpful in answering questions and keeping our table as organized as possible. I would definitely come again if I'm ever in the area.

our favorite ribs in Chicago.  Just fall off the bone good, very tender.  We get the zesty sauce, and it just compliments the ribs.  they have other sauces, and I hear that they are good, but there is no reason to order them.  Fries are good.  My wife once ordered a garlic chared steak, and that was very good as well.  it is very hard to find a table, if you dont come at 5 pm, or after 9 pm, you will wait 1-2 hours, so bring your drinking shoes, but even that is a hassel, because the bar area is packed.  they valet, 11 bucks, I think, because there really is no parking near the restaurant. but all of this is worth it for the ribs.  you will be buying the zesty sauce to take home with you.

I live down the street from Twin Anchors, so my five star review encompasses all of my trips.  In short, their ribs are amazing. The prohibition sauce starts off sweet, but finished with a perfect spiciness. Pro tip, they sell their sauce, and I often by bottles of the prohibition sauce to take home.  The ribs are the way to go. I have dabbled outside of the ribs- from the pulled park to today's chicken. STICK WITH THE RIBS.  Amazing restaurant. Live eating here on a regular basis.

Ribs way overdone - beyond "fall off the bone"! Pick up a rib and it's stripped, meat still on the plate. Prohibition sauce is good but ribs should require some "work"! Better choice is the burger. Great onion rings, creamed spinach and cole slaw. Friendly, attentive service.

Been here a number of times and they are coasting on reputation.  There are far better places to get BBQ in Chicago.  Far.  It's a traditional spot, but the food isn't very good.  The sauce is terrible, and the ribs are tasteless.  I think they steam em like White Castle does hamburgers. If you eat there, it's got a decent bar and booths.  It's an old fashioned relic out of another time.  The food needs to be updated though.  It's just not very good.

I used to go to Twin Anchors regularly 25 years ago.  I thought I would treat my dying father to a nice rib dinner so I got three 1/2 slabs to go. The ribs were inedible. They had some funky horse meat taste. They were dried out, not one ounce of moist let alone fall off the bone.  The bar b que sauce tasted like hunts tomato sauce out of a can. I had to pull the Sweet Baby Rays out of the fridge.  I would have been better off driving through Portillos. Never again. The potatos were fine hard to miss on a baked potato and the little pumpernickel rolls were much better than the ribs.
Anyone who has scene the Dark Knight should visit this bar just to se the marks on the bar from the scene in the movie where Harvey Dent confront Detective Wertz.
Fun, old fashioned spot - not replicable. Ribs were tender and tasty. Prices were low. Split a rack with someone you love!

I just loved this place. I went months ago and forgot to review it, but it was an all around wonderful experience. I went for a sister's birthday who happens to be a huge fan of the movie Return to Me. There were 6 of us in our party, and we had a long wait for our table, but it was a super pleasant waiting experience. We had a couple of drinks at the bar and soaked up the friendly ambiance of the place as we waited. It's the kind of place where you know there are regulars, but you don't feel excluded if you're not one of them. It was friendly and the pulled pork I got with prohibition sauce, as well as the creamed spinach, were delicious. I'll be back!
Excellent rib joint with a local neighborhood feel.  Set in a little tavern on N. Sedgwick, TA is a casual place which serves the best ribs in town.  The wait can be long depending on the night.

I remember coming here years ago when I used to live in Chicago, and was excited to return last night.  The food is amazing!  Love their selection of bbq sauces, although the prohibition is my fav.  The service was quite disappointing...from the super rude hostess to the waitress, who made us feel like we were a bother to be there.  Perhaps is was an off night for both, but with so many other GREAT bbq places popping up in the city...I will likely be checking them out and not running back to Twin Anchors.

I have to give it a 5, simply cuz I'm impressed. I had a pulled pork sandwich (it's been a thing for me lately), and he had ribs.  They were very tasty, and the meat was juicy. The Prohibition sauce. Absolutely worth trying! It's got a smokey heat to it. Too much of it would overwhelm my palate, but it's definitely complex. For my side, I got the creamed spinach. Honestly, I didn't care for it, but my cole slaw was enough. And really, it was alot of food! Service was very attentive. I actually liked that this place had good food, a vintage feel, and was a tad on the quieter side. More intimate. That old Chicago feel. I would definitely come back, and have already recommended it to others. We paired with wine (i loved the pinot noir I had. He had beer... and there was a plentiful craft beer menu). For all other foodies, I'd definitely add this place in as a spot for comparison on your Ribs-list.

I have to admit, I was pretty disappointed with my experience at Twin Anchors.  The ribs were excellent.  They fell off the bone, but it would be nice if they had a normal BBQ sauce.  Of our party of four we all ordered different sauces so I had the opportunity to try every sauce they offer.  I see where the sauce has its charm, but you need to have a pallet designed for the unique to really appreciate it. The big downfall, though, was the service.  Not only did our server come to our table last each time she visited the patio, despite being sat prior to either of the tables we were next to, but we ended up waiting twenty minutes after we were done eating to finally be able to leave because the check was so slow.  I know we're college-aged kids, but we make good money, we know how to tip, we shouldn't be designated the lowest priority just because we are young.  We were sat outside (which is no big deal since we said we were willing to eat outside), and when the food runner chose to fill my already full water cup, she spilled the ice cold water (on top of an already chilly night) all over my pants.  This was greeted with a very curt "sorry," after which I was given a clean towel and nothing more was said on the matter.  There was a very obvious lack of training.  I spent the rest of my night shivering. To top it off, the beers are exorbitantly expensive.  $7.50 for a white ale?  Absurd.  I don't expect to dine here again, which is too bad, with the atmosphere and the way they cook their ribs this restaurant has so much potential.

Simply my favorite restaurant in Chicago. Paul and his team serve barbecue ribs that are delicious and fall off the bone.  Their hospitality is second to none. And the bonus is that the atmosphere is very nostalgic.  Whenever we come to Chicago from Omaha, Twin Anchors is on the agenda.
It's been decades since I have been hear! Minor changes but it is still a great neighborhood spot! Busy! Outdoor seating! Awesome beer lists!
What a great restaurant/bar with a really cool story and past. Some of the best ribs I have ever eaten. The prohibition sauce is amazing!!
Great food, ribs were fall off the bone finger licking good!! Only downfall was the bar didn't have hardly any mixture we wanted. I would return, our server Debbie was super sweet!

OMG... Best ribs I have ever had.   This restaurant / bar is an institution.   From history on line and in the menu, it's been around forever.   The reviews are spot on, be ready for a wait for a table.  If you are a party of 2 or 4, it's much easier then 6+.    Many booths and tables accommodate the smaller groups.    Waiting is not bad, as the bar is hopping with all the people waiting.   We went on a Wednesday night, and still had to wait an hour for a table.   (party of six).    I do have to admit that I didn't really even look at the menu.   Everything I heard was ribs ribs ribs.   I jokingly asked the waitress for chicken tender kids meal, she said they have that but suggested the grill cheese for the kids.   Good to know that I could take the picky kids here and they could get something to eat too.    Everybody ordered ribs, half slab or full slab.   The full was perfect for me.   The half looked perfect for the ladies at the table.   I do suggest that when I do bring my wife I'll make her order the full slab so I can have some leftovers for the next day.   The sauce comes on the side.    I tried the regular and the prohibition.   Both were outstanding.   I like ribs, I like to cook ribs, and these were the best ribs I've ever had. They weren't completely fall off the bone eat with a fork, nor were they chew up the bone like a Kansas City rib.   They were just perfect.    Bottom line is this is an event destination.  Bring your patience in waiting for a table.  Enjoy the bar and having a few drinks.  And when you finally sit down make sure you order the ribs.

I don't know what else they serve on the menu, because the minute I sit down, I always order the exact same thing. Full slab of ribs with fries and a beer. Never disappointed in over 8 years. The ribs are exactly the way I love them. They fall right off the bone. Yummy! They do not accept reservations, so at times there is a bit of a wait for a table. They have a bar, which is constantly busy. They have valet, cause parking can get a bit tricky in this lovely neighborhood.

I went to dinner here for the first time this past weekend with some family that lives in the area.  Seeing as it was my first time I had to get the ribs and they didn't fail to impress.  We also ordered a bunch of sides and shared.  My son was a big fan of their beer selection.        The prices are reasonable and the service was very good as well.  It's a small location so there was a wait and the seating was a bit crowded but well worth it for how good the food was.  I'd definitely like to get back there again some time.

This restaurant has been a family favorite for years!! Whenever we all get in town this is the first place we stop. Every meal I have had here has been phenomenal! If your looking for good ribs this is the place to go. I always get the full slab and its enough for me and to share, they rock! Great little spot with great prices and great food!

I have not been here since before the internet. Okay, There may have been email, but there certainly were no Yelpers. I returned with my wife recently for my birthday lunch.  I remembered this place as being good, but could not recall details. We both had the famous ribs (I think they are baby back ribs). The full slab is enough food and delicious. The wife ordered a half slab and wanted more. The original zesty sauce is not impressive.  It is no better than the sauce you can get at the grocery store, Heinz, etc.  I strongly recommend the prohibition sauce.  For some reason, my full slab was cooked perfectly while the wife's half slab was slightly undercooked.  The sides - baked beans and onion rings were good. Cole slaw was good to go. I ordered a cup of the chili with cheese and onions. It was good as well.  Service was good. The waiter refilled my iced tea a number of times.
The ribs here are to DIE for.  Also, the bar is great--very, very affordable, great beers. Check it out for sure.

Twin Anchors is an unassuming little place from the outside. But it's popular for a reason, as I quickly found out yesterday. I went there for dinner with a family member. We both got the ribs with zesty sauce, and a bowl of prohibition sauce on the side. (Yes, this is the sauce-heavy style of bbq, not the dry rub. I don't mind it, but I know some people do.) Both sauces were great. The prohibition was smokier and spicier, although it's not THAT spicy. The zesty was a bit sweeter but still tangy. The ribs themselves were delicious. Very tender. By the end of the rack I was having trouble getting the meat to stay on the bones when I separated the next bone, but that's what forks are for. We both got full racks of ribs, and were glad we did - even if it seems like too much food, it's so good you're going to eat it all. Trust me. As for the service, I'll note for fairness that we got there right at opening. So we got seated immediately in an almost-empty room, and our food was apparently the first dish out of the kitchen that night. But by the time we left an hour later, the restaurant was almost full. Our waitress checked on us about once every ten minutes, and was very friendly and helpful. The restaurant was clean, including the bathrooms. Prices are reasonable for what you get, even drink prices($7 for an import beer, $5 for a rum and pineapple juice cocktail).

Twin Anchors is a classic Chicago Restaurant! Buried in Old Town, in the middle of houses and schools lies this amazing BBQ restaurant that hasn't moved away from it's core values in 80+ years. I've probably been here 10 times in the past year, if you are in yours 20's and your parents are from Chicago, chances are, you've been here too, or at least your parents have. The bartenders here are awesome and very friendly, probably some of the best bartenders in Chicago. I can't tell you how many bars I've been to where I stand at the bar for 10 minutes trying to order a drink, Twin Anchors you never wait more than a few minutes for a drink, even the most packed night, I don't know how they do it but big shout out to them. They also have Gumball Head on draft! Amazing beer! The food is all great, I usually get the ribs with their famous zesty sauce, sometimes Prohibition if I want something spicier. You can't go wrong though. The service is always fast, even when they are slammed, and always friendly.It's a family run restaurant after all. Be prepared to wait for at least 45 minutes to 1 hour if you show up here on a Friday or Saturday night. In the summers it can get pretty busy Thursday nights as well.  Overall definitely don't miss out on this timeless little Chicago restaurant!

I've eaten from here a few times and always enjoyed it until last night. I always have the vegetarian sandwich but last night it tasted different and had a different consistency than the other times. A couple of hours later and my stomach started doing somersaults, not good. I was up all night feeling nauseas and still don't feel great the day after. I won't be eating here again.

The ribs were delicious as was the BBQ sauce.  The chicken wings could have been a little less fatty but they were still very good. We did end up going around 6 pm on Monday so I'm not sure how crazy this place gets but it was like we were eating inside of a ship.  Great place and it's been there since the 1930's!

Great little spot.  Unpretentious, decent prices, good food.  Wonderful ribs.  We tried the ribs with onion rings.  Onion rings were good but The seating can feel bit crammed when it's crowded it's a cute casual spot for some great tender saucy ribs. Nice spicy sauce.
